top_insights.title: Consistent sector 3 slowdown
top_insights.detail: Multiple cars lose 0.8–1.2s in S3 during warm-up laps.

top_insights.title: Tire degradation window
top_insights.detail: Tire surface temp rises by ~6–9°C over 8 laps; expected cliff at lap ~18.

recommendations.message: Brake 3m later in Sector 2 to carry speed

top_insights.title: Brake fade in long downhill zones
top_insights.detail: Several vehicles show +7C caliper rise per lap.

top_insights.title: Late apex gains
top_insights.detail: Cluster 1 drivers gaining ~0.4s via later turn-in at T5.

recommendations.message: Smoother throttle pickup at corner exit

top_insights.title: High-speed esses consistency
top_insights.detail: Cluster 0 drivers remain within ±0.03s delta in S1.

top_insights.title: Oversteer trend
top_insights.detail: Rear slip angle increases 0.06°/lap under high load corners.

recommendations.message: Earlier rotation before S-turn entries

track_characteristics.layout_type: Technical road course with elevation changes
critical_sections: Sector 3 (T10-T12): Tight hairpin and final complex

top_insights.title: Hairpin braking variance at Turn 11
top_insights.detail: Significant performance spread of ±0.5s under heavy braking at T11 hairpin. Cluster 2 drivers (top performers) brake 8-12 meters later than Cluster 0, maintaining 15-20 km/h higher entry speed. Analysis shows optimal brake pressure curve: 85% initial, trailing to 45% at turn-in point. Drivers who maintain trail-braking through 40% of corner radius gain 0.2-0.3s per lap.

top_insights.title: Grip loss on off-camber sections in Sector 2
top_insights.detail: Rear traction drops 3-5% consistently in S2, particularly through Turns 6-8. Off-camber nature of Turn 7 (carousel) causes 0.15-0.25° additional slip angle compared to on-camber corners. Tire surface temperature differential between inside and outside edges reaches 8-12°C in these sections. Cluster 1 drivers compensate by using 5-8% less steering input and relying more on throttle modulation.

top_insights.title: Elevation change impact on Turn 2 braking zone
top_insights.detail: Uphill braking into Turn 2 creates unique load transfer dynamics. Top performers (Cluster 2) show 12-15% higher brake pressure application compared to flat sections, with peak deceleration reaching 1.8g. Vehicles that maintain brake bias at 58-62% front show superior stability. Entry speed variance of ±8 km/h directly correlates with 0.3-0.5s lap time difference.

top_insights.title: Sector 1 exit speed critical for lap time
top_insights.detail: Speed carried through Turn 4 onto the back straight determines 40% of overall lap time variance. Cluster 2 drivers exit T4 at 142-148 km/h vs 135-140 km/h for Cluster 0, translating to 0.4-0.6s advantage by Turn 7. Key factor is early throttle application (60% throttle at 30% corner exit) combined with minimal steering correction.

top_insights.title: Tire degradation pattern shows two-stage drop
top_insights.detail: Tire performance follows distinct two-stage degradation: gradual 2-3% loss per lap from laps 1-12, then accelerated 5-7% loss from laps 13-18. Surface temperature rises from 88°C (lap 1) to 102°C (lap 15), with inside edge showing 6-8°C higher than outside. Optimal pit window identified at lap 15-16 before performance cliff at lap 18-19.

top_insights.title: Turn 7 carousel entry technique variance
top_insights.detail: The off-camber Turn 7 carousel shows largest driver technique spread. Top performers use late apex strategy (apex at 65% of corner), maintaining 5-8 km/h higher mid-corner speed. Cluster 0 drivers apex too early (40-45%), causing understeer and requiring 0.2-0.3s correction. Optimal line uses 70% of track width on entry, 85% at exit.

top_insights.title: Sector 3 consistency determines race position
top_insights.detail: Final sector (T10-T12) shows highest correlation with race finishing position (R²=0.73). Drivers with Sector 3 consistency within ±0.15s maintain positions, while variance >0.25s leads to position loss. Turn 11 hairpin exit speed directly impacts Turn 12 entry, with optimal sequence showing 0.8-1.2s total sector time for top performers.

top_insights.title: Weather sensitivity in morning sessions
top_insights.detail: Track temperature below 25°C causes 2-4% grip reduction, particularly affecting Turn 2 and Turn 11 braking zones. Cold track conditions show 0.3-0.5s slower lap times until lap 8-10 when rubber builds. Humidity above 65% correlates with 1-2% additional tire temperature, requiring earlier pit window consideration.

sector_1.key_characteristics: High-speed entry from start/finish, critical elevation change at T2, technical T3-T4 complex

performance_factors.braking_zone_t2: Uphill braking requires 12-15% higher pressure, optimal entry speed 165-170 km/h
performance_factors.elevation_impact: 174ft elevation change affects aero balance, requires 3-5% more downforce
performance_factors.exit_speed_t4: Critical for back straight, optimal exit 142-148 km/h

sector_2.key_characteristics: Technical off-camber sequence, Turn 7 carousel is most challenging, elevation undulation

performance_factors.off_camber_t7: 3-5% grip loss, requires 5-8% less steering input, optimal apex at 65% of corner
performance_factors.tire_temp_differential: 8-12°C inside/outside edge temp difference causes handling variance
performance_factors.throttle_modulation: Cluster 1 drivers use progressive throttle (40%→60%→85%) vs binary on/off

sector_3.key_characteristics: Tight hairpin at T11, final complex at T12, critical for race position

performance_factors.hairpin_braking: 8-12m later braking for top performers, 85%→45% brake pressure curve optimal
performance_factors.trail_braking: Maintaining 40% brake through 40% of corner radius gains 0.2-0.3s
performance_factors.exit_sequence: T11 exit speed directly impacts T12 entry, optimal sequence 0.8-1.2s total

tire_wear_analysis.degradation_pattern: Two-stage: gradual 2-3% per lap (laps 1-12), accelerated 5-7% per lap (laps 13-18)

wear_indicators.pressure_evolution: Starts at 22.5 PSI, rises to 24.8 PSI by lap 15

track_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Uphill sections increase load, causing 2-3% additional wear
track_specific_factors.off_camber_corners: T7 carousel shows 15-20% higher inside edge wear
track_specific_factors.braking_zones: T2 and T11 heavy braking zones show 8-12% front tire wear concentration

cluster_0_characteristics.description: Conservative driving style, early braking, lower entry speeds

cluster_1_characteristics.description: Balanced approach, good technique, moderate aggression

cluster_2_characteristics.description: Aggressive, late braking, high entry speeds, optimal technique

recommendations.rationale: Two-stage degradation pattern shows optimal window at lap 15-16, before performance cliff at lap 18-19. Tire temperature reaches 102°C at lap 15, with inside edge at 108°C. Waiting beyond lap 16 risks 5-7% performance loss and potential position loss.

alternative_windows.note: Early but safe, preserves tire life

recommendations.message: Trail-brake slightly longer into T7 carousel, maintaining 40% brake pressure through 40% of corner radius. This will improve entry speed by 3-5 km/h and reduce understeer in off-camber section.
Brake 8-12 meters later into Turn 11 hairpin, using progressive brake pressure curve: 85% initial, trailing to 45% at turn-in. Maintain trail-braking through 40% of corner radius.
Focus on Turn 4 exit speed - apply 60% throttle at 30% corner exit, minimize steering correction. Target exit speed 142-148 km/h for optimal back straight performance.
Consider 58-62% front brake bias for Turn 2 uphill braking zone. Slight increase in front downforce (3-5%) may help with elevation changes and off-camber sections.
Monitor inside edge tire temperature in Sector 2 - differential above 10°C indicates excessive wear. Reduce steering input by 5-8% in off-camber corners to preserve tire life.

temperature_effects.above_35c: 1-2% grip loss, 2-3°C higher tire temps, earlier pit window

humidity_effects.above_65: 2-3% additional tire temperature, consider earlier pit window

wind_effects.headwind_back_straight: 3-5 km/h speed reduction, affects Turn 7 entry
wind_effects.crosswind_sector_2: Requires 2-3% steering correction in off-camber sections

track_characteristics.layout_type: High-speed flowing circuit with elevation changes and technical sections
primary_challenges: High-speed esses (Oak Tree to Roller Coaster)
critical_sections: Sector 2: Technical infield and elevation changes (T6-T10)
Sector 3: Fast flowing section to finish (T11-T17)

top_insights.title: High-speed rolling pace in upper esses
top_insights.detail: Cluster 1 and Cluster 2 drivers show +2.1-3.5 km/h advantage through the upper esses (T3-T5). Top performers maintain minimum speed of 185-192 km/h through the sequence, while Cluster 0 drivers drop to 178-185 km/h. Key factor is minimal steering input (8-12° vs 15-20° for slower drivers) and maintaining throttle at 85-95% through the complex. Speed carried here directly impacts the following straight, with 0.4-0.6s lap time correlation.

top_insights.title: Brake stability degradation after lap 10
top_insights.detail: ABS activation frequency increases 35-45% after lap 10, particularly in Turn 1 (uphill braking) and Turn 10 (Roller Coaster entry). Brake pad temperature rises from 420°C (lap 1) to 580°C (lap 15), causing 8-12% reduction in initial bite. Top performers mitigate this by using 5-8% less initial brake pressure and relying more on engine braking. Brake bias adjustment from 60% front to 58% front after lap 10 shows 0.2-0.3s improvement.

top_insights.title: Roller Coaster section (T10-T12) critical for lap time
top_insights.detail: The Roller Coaster section shows highest time variance across the field. Top performers (Cluster 2) navigate this section in 12.8-13.2s, while Cluster 0 requires 14.1-14.6s. Key is maintaining momentum through the elevation changes - optimal technique uses 70-75% throttle through T10, minimal lift at T11 crest, and early throttle application at T12. Speed carried through this section determines 30% of overall lap time variance.

top_insights.title: Turn 1 uphill braking zone technique variance
top_insights.detail: Uphill braking into Turn 1 creates unique challenges with 200ft elevation change. Top performers brake 10-15 meters later, using 15-18% higher brake pressure than flat sections. Optimal entry speed is 195-200 km/h, with brake pressure curve: 90% initial, trailing to 50% at turn-in. Drivers who maintain trail-braking through 35% of corner radius gain 0.3-0.4s. Entry speed variance of ±10 km/h correlates with 0.5-0.7s lap time difference.

top_insights.title: Infield technical section (T6-T9) consistency determines race position
top_insights.detail: The technical infield section shows highest correlation with race finishing position (R²=0.68). Consistency within ±0.2s maintains positions, while variance >0.3s leads to position loss. Turn 8 (tight right-hander) is particularly critical - optimal technique uses late apex (65% of corner), maintaining 3-5% throttle through mid-corner to prevent understeer. Cluster 2 drivers show 0.4-0.6s advantage in this section.

top_insights.title: Tire temperature management critical in high-speed sections
top_insights.detail: High-speed sections (T3-T5, T13-T17) cause rapid tire temperature rise. Surface temperature increases from 90°C (lap 1) to 108°C (lap 12) in these zones. Top performers manage this by using 5-8% less steering input in esses, reducing scrub. Tire temperature differential between high-speed and technical sections reaches 8-12°C, requiring careful management to prevent oversteer in technical sections.

top_insights.title: South Bend (T14) exit speed critical for final sector
top_insights.detail: Turn 14 exit speed directly impacts final sector performance. Top performers exit at 165-172 km/h vs 158-165 km/h for slower drivers. Key is early throttle application (60% at 25% corner exit) and using full track width. Speed carried here determines 0.3-0.5s advantage through the final flowing section to the finish line.

top_insights.title: Elevation change impact on aero balance
top_insights.detail: 200ft elevation change affects aero balance throughout the lap. Uphill sections (T1, T10) require 5-8% more downforce, while downhill sections (T5, T12) benefit from lower drag. Top performers adjust driving style: more aggressive in downhill sections (carrying 5-8 km/h more speed), more conservative in uphill sections (preserving momentum). This technique gains 0.2-0.4s per lap.

top_insights.title: Tire degradation shows linear pattern with acceleration after lap 14
top_insights.detail: Tire performance shows linear 2-3% degradation per lap from laps 1-14, then accelerated 6-8% degradation from laps 15-18. Surface temperature progression: 90°C (lap 1) → 98°C (lap 8) → 105°C (lap 14) → 112°C (lap 18). Optimal pit window identified at lap 16-17, before performance cliff at lap 18-19. Inside edge shows 8-10°C higher temperature than outside edge.

sector_1.key_characteristics: High-speed entry, critical uphill braking at T1, flowing esses (T3-T5), elevation changes

performance_factors.uphill_braking_t1: 10-15m later braking for top performers, 90%→50% brake pressure curve, optimal entry 195-200 km/h
performance_factors.upper_esses: Minimal steering input (8-12°), maintain 85-95% throttle, target speed 185-192 km/h
performance_factors.elevation_impact: 200ft elevation change requires 5-8% more downforce, affects aero balance

sector_2.key_characteristics: Technical infield section, tight corners, Roller Coaster section (T10-T12), elevation changes

performance_factors.infield_consistency: Turn 8 late apex (65%), maintain 3-5% throttle through mid-corner, critical for race position
performance_factors.roller_coaster: Maintain momentum through elevation, 70-75% throttle T10, minimal lift T11, early throttle T12
performance_factors.brake_management: Brake pad temp rises to 580°C, use 5-8% less initial pressure, adjust bias to 58% front

sector_3.key_characteristics: Fast flowing section, South Bend (T14), final complex to finish

performance_factors.south_bend_exit: Critical exit speed 165-172 km/h, early throttle (60% at 25% exit), use full track width
performance_factors.high_speed_flow: Maintain momentum, minimal steering corrections, tire temp management critical
performance_factors.final_complex: Consistency key, optimal line through T15-T17 gains 0.2-0.3s

tire_wear_analysis.degradation_pattern: Linear 2-3% per lap (laps 1-14), accelerated 6-8% per lap (laps 15-18)

wear_indicators.pressure_evolution: Starts at 22.8 PSI, rises to 25.2 PSI by lap 16

track_specific_factors.high_speed_sections: T3-T5 and T13-T17 cause rapid temp rise, 8-12°C differential vs technical sections
track_specific_factors.braking_zones: T1 and T10 heavy braking show 10-15% front tire wear concentration
track_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Uphill sections increase load, causing 3-4% additional wear

cluster_0_characteristics.description: Conservative approach, early braking, lower entry speeds, high consistency

cluster_1_characteristics.description: Balanced performance, good high-speed technique, moderate aggression

cluster_2_characteristics.description: Aggressive, optimal technique, high entry speeds, excellent momentum

recommendations.rationale: Linear degradation pattern shows optimal window at lap 16-17, before performance cliff at lap 18-19. Tire temperature reaches 105°C at lap 14, rising to 112°C by lap 18. Brake pad temperature also critical - reaches 580°C by lap 15, affecting stability.

alternative_windows.note: Early but safe, preserves tire and brake life
Maximum tire usage, slight risk of performance drop

recommendations.message: Reduce steering input mid-esses (T3-T5) to avoid scrubbing speed. Maintain 8-12° steering angle vs 15-20°, and keep throttle at 85-95% through the complex. Target minimum speed of 185-192 km/h.

Brake 10-15 meters later into Turn 1 uphill braking zone. Use progressive brake pressure: 90% initial, trailing to 50% at turn-in. Maintain trail-braking through 35% of corner radius. Target entry speed 195-200 km/h.

Focus on Roller Coaster section (T10-T12) - maintain momentum through elevation changes. Use 70-75% throttle through T10, minimal lift at T11 crest, early throttle application at T12. Target section time 12.8-13.2s.
Turn 8 (infield) - use late apex at 65% of corner, maintain 3-5% throttle through mid-corner to prevent understeer. Consistency in infield section is critical for race position.
South Bend (T14) exit speed critical - apply 60% throttle at 25% corner exit, use full track width. Target exit speed 165-172 km/h for optimal final sector performance.

After lap 10, adjust brake bias from 60% front to 58% front to improve stability as brake pad temperature rises. Consider 5-8% more downforce for uphill sections, but balance with drag for high-speed sections.

Monitor tire temperature in high-speed sections (T3-T5, T13-T17) - reduce steering input by 5-8% to prevent excessive temperature rise. Maintain 8-12°C differential between high-speed and technical sections.

temperature_effects.below_20c: 3-5% grip reduction, 0.4-0.6s slower until lap 10-12, brake pad requires 2-3 laps to reach optimal temp
temperature_effects.above_30c: 2-3% grip loss, 3-5°C higher tire temps, earlier pit window, brake pad temp rises faster

humidity_effects.50_70: 2-3% additional tire temperature, brake pad cooling affected
humidity_effects.above_70: 3-4% additional tire temperature, brake pad cooling significantly reduced, consider earlier pit window

wind_effects.headwind_sector_1: 4-6 km/h speed reduction in esses, affects momentum
wind_effects.crosswind_sector_2: Requires 3-4% steering correction in technical sections
wind_effects.tailwind_sector_3: 3-5 km/h speed gain, but affects braking zones

track_characteristics.layout_type: Technical, flowing circuit with elevation changes and compression zones
critical_sections: Sector 1: High-speed entry and technical sequence (T1-T5)
Sector 2: Flowing middle section with elevation (T6-T10)

top_insights.title: Mid-corner stiffness variation in compression zones
top_insights.detail: Cars show 0.05–0.09° variance in roll stiffness, particularly in compression zones (T6, T9, T12). Top performers (Cluster 2) maintain consistent chassis attitude with minimal roll variation (±0.02°), while Cluster 0 shows 0.08-0.12° variation. This variance directly correlates with 0.2-0.4s lap time difference. Key factor is suspension setup and driver technique - maintaining smooth inputs through compression zones prevents chassis upset and maintains tire contact patch.

top_insights.title: Acceleration delta out of Turn 4
top_insights.detail: Cluster 2 vehicles gain +0.3-0.5s out of T4 via earlier throttle application. Top performers apply 60% throttle at 35% corner exit vs 40% throttle at 50% exit for slower drivers. This technique maintains 5-8 km/h higher exit speed (148-155 km/h vs 140-148 km/h), which translates to 0.3-0.5s advantage by Turn 8. Key is maintaining rear traction while applying throttle - optimal technique uses progressive throttle application (40%→60%→85%) rather than binary on/off.

top_insights.title: Museum Corner (T5) entry technique critical
top_insights.detail: Turn 5 (Museum Corner) shows largest performance spread across the field. Top performers use late apex strategy (apex at 70% of corner), maintaining 8-12 km/h higher mid-corner speed (125-132 km/h vs 115-125 km/h). Entry technique is key - optimal approach uses 85% of track width on entry, with brake pressure trailing from 80% to 30% at turn-in. Drivers who maintain trail-braking through 45% of corner radius gain 0.3-0.4s per lap.

top_insights.title: Compression zone handling determines sector times
top_insights.detail: Compression zones at T6, T9, and T12 show highest correlation with sector times (R²=0.71). Top performers maintain smooth inputs through compression, using 3-5% less steering input and maintaining 5-8% throttle to keep chassis settled. Cluster 0 drivers show 0.15-0.25s loss per compression zone due to chassis upset and tire load variation. Optimal technique: open steering 10-15% earlier in compression, maintain light throttle to keep rear loaded.

top_insights.title: Back straight entry speed variance
top_insights.detail: Speed carried onto the back straight (after T8) determines 35% of overall lap time variance. Top performers enter at 162-168 km/h vs 155-162 km/h for slower drivers. Key factors: T7 exit speed (optimal 138-145 km/h), T8 entry technique (late apex, maintain momentum), and early throttle application. Speed difference here translates to 0.4-0.6s advantage by Turn 11.

top_insights.title: Tire temperature management in flowing sections
top_insights.detail: Flowing middle section (T6-T10) causes rapid tire temperature rise due to sustained lateral load. Surface temperature increases from 90°C (lap 1) to 104°C (lap 14) in these zones. Top performers manage this by using 5-10% less steering input, reducing scrub. Tire temperature differential between flowing and technical sections reaches 6-10°C. Excessive temperature in flowing sections causes oversteer in subsequent technical sections (T11-T14).

top_insights.title: Final complex (T11-T17) consistency critical
top_insights.detail: Final technical complex shows highest correlation with race finishing position (R²=0.69). Consistency within ±0.18s maintains positions, while variance >0.25s leads to position loss. Turn 14 (tight left-hander) is particularly critical - optimal technique uses late apex (65% of corner), maintaining 2-4% throttle through mid-corner. Cluster 2 drivers show 0.5-0.7s advantage in this section through superior technique and consistency.

top_insights.title: Elevation change impact on Turn 1 braking
top_insights.detail: Uphill braking into Turn 1 creates unique load transfer. Top performers brake 8-12 meters later, using 12-15% higher brake pressure than flat sections. Optimal entry speed is 175-180 km/h, with brake pressure curve: 85% initial, trailing to 45% at turn-in. Drivers who maintain trail-braking through 40% of corner radius gain 0.2-0.3s. Entry speed variance of ±8 km/h correlates with 0.4-0.6s lap time difference.

top_insights.title: Tire degradation shows progressive pattern with acceleration after lap 15
top_insights.detail: Tire performance shows progressive 2-4% degradation per lap from laps 1-15, then accelerated 6-8% degradation from laps 16-19. Surface temperature progression: 90°C (lap 1) → 96°C (lap 8) → 104°C (lap 15) → 110°C (lap 19). Optimal pit window identified at lap 17-18, before performance cliff at lap 19-20. Inside edge shows 7-9°C higher temperature than outside edge, particularly in compression zones.

top_insights.title: Suspension setup variance affects compression zone performance
top_insights.detail: Suspension setup shows significant impact on compression zone performance. Vehicles with softer rear suspension (15-20% softer) show 0.2-0.3s advantage in compression zones (T6, T9, T12) due to better chassis compliance. However, this comes at cost of 0.1-0.2s in high-speed sections. Optimal setup balances compression zone performance with high-speed stability.

sector_1.key_characteristics: High-speed entry, uphill braking at T1, technical sequence, Museum Corner (T5)

performance_factors.uphill_braking_t1: 8-12m later braking for top performers, 85%→45% brake pressure curve, optimal entry 175-180 km/h
performance_factors.turn_4_exit: Critical acceleration zone, 60% throttle at 35% exit, target 148-155 km/h exit speed
performance_factors.museum_corner: Late apex at 70%, maintain 8-12 km/h higher mid-corner speed, trail-brake through 45%

sector_2.key_characteristics: Flowing middle section, compression zones (T6, T9), elevation changes, back straight entry

performance_factors.compression_zones: Open steering 10-15% earlier, maintain 5-8% throttle, 3-5% less steering input, smooth inputs critical
performance_factors.tire_temp_management: 5-10% less steering input to reduce scrub, prevent 6-10°C temp differential
performance_factors.back_straight_entry: Target entry speed 162-168 km/h, key factors: T7 exit (138-145 km/h), T8 technique

sector_3.key_characteristics: Technical final complex, tight corners, critical for race position

performance_factors.turn_14_technique: Late apex at 65%, maintain 2-4% throttle through mid-corner, critical for consistency
performance_factors.final_complex_consistency: Within ±0.18s maintains positions, variance >0.25s leads to position loss
performance_factors.chassis_settlement: Smooth inputs prevent chassis upset, maintain tire contact patch

tire_wear_analysis.degradation_pattern: Progressive 2-4% per lap (laps 1-15), accelerated 6-8% per lap (laps 16-19)

wear_indicators.pressure_evolution: Starts at 22.6 PSI, rises to 25.0 PSI by lap 17

track_specific_factors.compression_zones: T6, T9, T12 show 12-15% higher inside edge wear due to load transfer
track_specific_factors.flowing_sections: Sustained lateral load in T6-T10 causes rapid temp rise, 6-10°C differential
track_specific_factors.braking_zones: T1 and T5 heavy braking show 8-12% front tire wear concentration

cluster_0_characteristics.description: Conservative approach, early braking, lower entry speeds, struggles with compression zones

cluster_1_characteristics.description: Balanced performance, good technique, moderate aggression, handles compression zones well

cluster_2_characteristics.description: Aggressive, optimal technique, high entry speeds, excellent compression zone handling

recommendations.rationale: Progressive degradation pattern shows optimal window at lap 17-18, before performance cliff at lap 19-20. Tire temperature reaches 104°C at lap 15, rising to 110°C by lap 19. Compression zones cause additional wear, requiring careful management.

alternative_windows.note: Early but safe, preserves tire life
Maximum tire usage, slight risk of performance drop

recommendations.message: Open steering earlier in compression zones (T6, T9, T12) - 10-15% earlier steering input. Maintain 5-8% throttle to keep rear loaded and chassis settled. Use 3-5% less steering input overall to prevent chassis upset.

Turn 4 exit - apply 60% throttle at 35% corner exit (not 50%). Use progressive throttle application (40%→60%→85%) rather than binary on/off. Target exit speed 148-155 km/h for optimal back straight performance.
Museum Corner (T5) - use late apex at 70% of corner, maintain 8-12 km/h higher mid-corner speed (125-132 km/h). Trail-brake through 45% of corner radius. Use 85% of track width on entry.
Back straight entry - focus on T7 exit speed (target 138-145 km/h) and T8 entry technique (late apex, maintain momentum). Target entry speed onto back straight 162-168 km/h.
Turn 14 (final complex) - use late apex at 65% of corner, maintain 2-4% throttle through mid-corner to prevent understeer. Consistency in final complex is critical for race position.

Consider softer rear suspension (15-20% softer) for better compression zone compliance, but balance with high-speed stability. Slight increase in front downforce (3-5%) may help with Turn 1 uphill braking.

Monitor tire temperature in flowing sections (T6-T10) - use 5-10% less steering input to reduce scrub and prevent excessive temperature rise. Maintain 6-10°C differential between flowing and technical sections.

temperature_effects.above_32c: 1-2% grip loss, 2-4°C higher tire temps, earlier pit window

humidity_effects.above_70: 2-3% additional tire temperature, consider earlier pit window

wind_effects.headwind_back_straight: 3-5 km/h speed reduction, affects T8 entry
wind_effects.crosswind_sector_2: Requires 2-3% steering correction in compression zones
